title: Specific heat - steel sphere in water

content.question: A <math alttext="0.85 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.85</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math> steel sphere initially has a temperature of <math alttext="700 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>700</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>. The specific heat of steel is <math alttext="c sub S equals, 490 joules per kilogram kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>c</mi><mtext>s</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>490</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>J/</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The sphere is submerged in a container that holds <math alttext="4.0 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math> of water initially at a temperature of <math alttext="300 kelvins" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>. The specific heat of water is <math alttext="c sub W equals, 4180 joules per kilogram kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>c</mi><mtext>w</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4180</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>J/</mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is approximately equal to the final temperature of the water and sphere after they reach thermodynamic equilibrium, assuming they are thermally isolated from the surroundings?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
